newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine property stocks seen taking a breather.
newsitem.headline: Philippine property stocks seen taking a breather.

text.p: Philippine property stocks, long a market favourite, may have been battered in recent sessions but brokers said on Monday the sector's boom is far from over.

"Our view is that fundamentals of the sector are firm but it's really sentiment-driven. The sentiment is really bad from the foreign side," Colbert Nocum, an analyst of ING Barings Securities, told Reuters.

The Philippine Stock Exchange's property sub-index, which represents about 25 percent of total market capitalisation, reached a record high of 179.38 on July 5, a 50 percent jump from the start of this year.
It has corrected by almost 15 percent since then and closed at 152.69 on Monday, a further fall of 2.78 points.
Analysts are advising investors to buy on dips, or be selective on property stocks.
"Our recommendation is to be selective. We're not bullish on the office sector but on the residential sector," said Barrie del Rosario, an analyst at DBP Daiwa Securities.

ING Barings' Nocum said that, despite expectations of falling domestic interest rates, foreign investors will remain cautious over real estate since they have been hurt before in Thailand and Malaysia.
In both places, property prices had fallen following an oversupply in response to strong initial demand for real estate in the early 1990s, Nocum said.
Angping Securities was even more positive, saying in an advisory to clients: "We would treat further corrections as opportunities for a 'screaming buy' position."
The brokerage added that property prices are not likely to have a huge correction even if the real estate market cools down.
ING Barings estimates the property sector is trading at 24 times forecast 1996 earnings versus the market's 17 to 18 times.
Francisco Licuanan, president of Ayala Land Inc, told Reuters land prices in the premiere financial district of Makati had gone up by 50 percent in the past year and a half.
He estimated that land along Ayala Avenue, the district's most prestigious street, is now fetching about 430,000 pesos per sq metre more more.
Real land prices have more than tripled in residential areas just outside Manila, such in Laguna, Batangas, Rizal and Bulacan, due to the high demand for housing, he said.
Despite the huge jump in real estate prices, Licuanan said he was optimistic for the future, as long as the economy keeps growing.
"As long as the economy is strong, the medium term view is land will go up. All property prices were relatively low. They're only catching up now," he said.
